quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Someone has to be in charge of each camp‚Äîor chaos ensues!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your expedition has reached basecamp with 200 porters, 50 climbers, equipment managers, medical staff, and logistics coordinators. Decisions need to be made: Should we push to Camp 2 tomorrow or wait for weather to clear? Who approves the medical decisions for ill climbers? Who can authorize spending from the emergency fund? Who reports to the sponsor? A medical emergency happens at 2 AM‚Äîwho makes the decision?
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's missing from your expedition structure?

options.A: Clear governance structure defining roles, authorities, escalation paths, and decision-making rules
options.B: More experienced people in leadership positions
options.D: A written manual covering every possible scenario

insights.explanation: Every critical decision needs a clear owner. Authority levels must be defined: Who can approve what? At what escalation level does it go to sponsor? Who has veto power?
insights.pmbokSupport: Governance defines roles, responsibilities, and decision rights across the project

insights.explanation: Governance documents decision criteria, approval authorities, and escalation paths. This prevents decision paralysis, ensures consistency, and protects the project.
insights.pmbokSupport: Governance structure enables timely, consistent, informed decision-making

trapSection.explanation: Projects without clear governance end up with unclear authority, inconsistent decisions, and unnecessary escalations. It's chaos disguised as flexibility.

trapTable.violation: More experience doesn't solve unclear authority‚Äîpeople don't know who decides
Can't write a manual for every situation; you need decision-making principles instead

checklist: Are roles and responsibilities clearly defined?
Who has authority to approve scope changes?
Who has authority to approve budget changes?
What decisions go to the sponsor?
How frequently does governance body meet?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Good governance = clear roles + defined authorities + escalation paths + decision criteria + transparent communication.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Strong governance provides clarity, consistency, and timely decision-making:

rows.action: Identify all stakeholder groups and decision-making bodies: Sponsor, Steering Committee, Project Manager, Change Control Board, Quality Board, etc.
Define each role: PM does what? Sponsor does what? CCB does what? Quality Board? Use RACI matrix if needed. Clear responsibility prevents finger-pointing.
Define authorization limits: PM can approve changes up to $5K. Sponsor approves above that. PM can approve scope changes up to 5%. Sponsor approves above that.
Define how decisions are made: By consensus? Majority vote? Single decision-maker? What factors matter (cost, schedule, quality, risk)? Document decision criteria.
rows.examKeywords: Decision criteria, Decision authority, Governance rules

rows.action: Define escalation: If PM can't resolve ‚Üí Sponsor. If sponsor can't ‚Üí Executive steering. Emergency path: Contact sponsor immediately. Clear path prevents delays.
Define governance meetings: Steering committee monthly? CCB weekly? Daily standup? Each meeting has agenda, decision owner, and documented outcomes.
rows.examKeywords: Meeting cadence, Governance meetings, Decision documentation

rows.action: Governance decisions must be communicated to all stakeholders. Who gets what info? When? Format? Ensure transparency and alignment.
Governance should evolve as project matures. Early stages: more control. Execution: more autonomy. Closeout: focus on lessons. Review governance periodically.

secondScenario.title: Apply S.T.R.U.C.T.U.R.E.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your $10M project has a Sponsor, PMO, Steering Committee, and Project Manager. A critical issue arises: The team discovered a major technical constraint that will cost $300K to resolve. The PM wants to escalate to the Sponsor. The PMO says go to Steering Committee. The Sponsor is on vacation for a week. The team needs a decision in 2 days to stay on schedule.
secondScenario.question: What's the governance problem, and how do you solve it?

options.A: Wait for Sponsor to return‚Äîmajor decisions need the top authority
options.B: Define approval authorities, escalation paths, and emergency decision processes upfront. PM should have authority to approve issues up to X amount with approval needed for larger amounts
options.C: CCB should make all major decisions regardless of amount
options.D: PM makes the decision independently and reports to Sponsor later

memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Expedition Command Center

story.title: Chain of Command on the Mountain
story.narrative: Every expedition needs a clear command structure so decisions happen fast and everyone knows their role...

scenes.description: Sponsor (back home), Expedition Commander, Camp Manager (each camp), Medical Officer, Logistics Chief, Climbing Teams. Who's part of governance? Who decides what?
Commander: Overall strategy and major decisions. Camp Manager: Daily logistics and safety at camp. Medical: All medical decisions. Logistics: Supply and porters. Each role is crystal clear.
Commander approves decisions over $50K. Camp Manager approves under $5K. Medical Officer has full authority on health decisions (no debate). Emergency: Act, then report.
Decision criteria: Schedule impact? Cost impact? Safety impact? Team morale? Push higher if multiple impacts. Weather delay = Camp Manager decides. Major route change = Commander.
Can't decide at camp? Ask Commander. Commander can't decide? Ask Sponsor (by radio). Medical emergency? Medical Officer decides immediately, reports later. Clear path = fast decisions.
Daily 6 AM briefing (all role holders). Weekly strategy meeting (Commander + Camp Manager + Medical). Weather decision: Daily 8 PM. Emergency: anytime.
All decisions announced immediately at briefing. Dispatch to Sponsor daily. Team knows who decided and why. No surprises, no whispers.
Mid-expedition review: Is structure working? Too many escalations? Not enough autonomy? Too slow? Adjust. By summit, governance has evolved with team experience.

story.moral: Commander **S**pecifies structure, **T**ailors roles, **R**equests authority, **U**nderstands criteria, **C**reates escalation, **T**racks meetings, **U**ses communication, **R**eviews & adapts.
